stories.title: Worms or bust: The story of Britain’s most tenacious indie games company (2016)

stories.text: I'm too lazy to run ad blockers. So I see plenty of advertising on the internet. Here's the thing: all the ads seem to be for things that I already bought. After I placed an order with Select Blinds, I started getting relentless Select Blinds ads on YouTube. After I made some charitable donations to Mercy Ships and Heifer International, their ads started following me around everywhere. My wife recently got on a new immunosuppressant medication, and now I see ads for that all the time. Great job targeting! But I already spent the money? So what is the point of all this?
stories.title: Ask HN: Does targeted advertising work at all?
Apple shocks iOS developers with 27% commission on third-party payments
I found eggs hatching in my printer
If it's too early to criticize it's too early to evangelize
Send your email right to the other person's spam

stories.text: Airdrop is so practical. I use it for exchanging links, photos, pdfs, and other files between my phone and my laptop (and between friends’ phones, etc.). I’m looking to move to android phones, because I need a fold phone, but I’m a bit worried that not having airdrop will complicate my life a lot. How do people who don’t have iPhones handle these tasks?
stories.title: Ask HN: How do people with Android phone do airdrop stuff?

stories.text:
Is it possible to create a black or whitelist for Chrome extensions that works per site? I tried "Extensions Manager", but it doesn't work as intended. Any specific ways to go about it? 
Specific scenario: For example, you don't want ad blocking on your banking website, but you want it for "rest of the web".
stories.title: Ask HN: Enable/disable Chrome extensions per site (via white or blacklist)
